Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2007 04:08PM TPPJ wrote: Hey there...  I'm from the Jan. 2007 group.  I did 4 a/c's followed by 12 weekly taxols.  The a/c was tolerable due to Emend, the anti nausea drug.  I was totally speeding from the steroids, so ativan and lunesta were a must.  Taxol was ok until about week 7, when I noticed my energy was draining.  I'd be calling it a night an hour earlier each day after each weeks infusion at that point.  I didn't lose my eyebrows or lashes until after the last taxol...  took me about 3 weeks to feel with it again.  After that, it's all good.
Posts.Title: 16 weekly Taxols-anyone else? bluewillow mrs_X_Sunneedazee

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 07:51PM TPPJ wrote: I did four a/c's two years ago this Dec. and due to Emend, I was totally fine.  I was a little hyper from the decadron, but...  all in all, it was well tolerated.  Not near the nightmare I expected.  Like clockwork, though, I lost my hair on day 18, just as I had been told by other survivors.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2007 01:37PM TPPJ wrote: Boy, not that I wish a high oncotype score on anyone, but my score is making me nervous: 44. I haven't seen anyone's score this high. I am 41 years old and had a 1.1 cm tumor, ER/PR/HER2+. I did 4 A/C's, 12 taxols, am currently doing 52 weeks of Herceptin and I began Tamoxifen last month.
Posts.Title: Oncotype Test Dkissel san4850

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 08:35AM TPPJ wrote: When they do the oncotype scoring, they test something like 20 different genes or factors (not sure of exact number).  I think each one and the amt. of each present carries a certain weight and that's how they determine the score.  I ended up being high...a 44.  I was HER2/neu positive though, so no matter what my oncotype score was, I was doing chemo.  My dr. felt my onco. score was high due to HER2/neu.  Oncotype doesn't factor in herceptin, though, so hopefully my score of 44 isn't accurate.  That score translated to something like a 30% risk of mets over ten years.  I've done all I can do for now.  I'm feeling good and until I feel otherwise, I'm just going to try to live my life.  I'm two years out now.
Posts.Title: OncotypeDX score, please help! moodyk13 otter

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2007 05:51PM TPPJ wrote: I'd try not to freak out. You are at a great place: the James. They know what they are doing there. I know after my mastectomy and TRAM flap reconstruction I developed lumpy patches in the new breast...it was muscle. Take it one step at at time... you can address your concerns with the onco. They'll do whatever needs to be done or put your mind at ease that things have been done correctly. Remember, it's an NCI CCC.... not all of us are so lucky to be in such a place.
Posts.Title: Completely FREAKING out rdelrigo roseg

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 04:29PM TPPJ wrote: I don't understand what the criteria is for having a port.  I had 4 A/C's, twelve taxols and nearly 52 herceptins without a port.  A port was never offered to me.  It got tough to get a vein at the end, but I did it...  I have heard some issues w/port removal from friends I've met on this site.
Posts.Title: Has anyone completed A/C tx successfully WITHOUT a port? deecsw MissUniverse

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2008 06:26AM TPPJ wrote: I've read that if a person develops new cancers they can have a different "personality", i.e. the may not be ER or her2/neu+.  Hope we never have to find out. I did all but my last 3 herceptins.  Developled cardiomyopathy discovered during an elective surgery.  I, too, notice strange vision changes as of late but I chalk it up to being 42.  Lots of my friends told me I'd be holding the newspaper far away once I hit 40, like clockworks.  They were right.  I also can't seem to tolerate my contacts as well as I did pre-chemo.
Posts.Title: Herceptin ellie123 ellie123

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 08:53AM TPPJ wrote: I had a TRAM in 9/06.  I can understand your desire for prophylactic mastectomy based on your history, but I think I'd go the implant route vs. TRAM.  The recovery from the TRAM was huge and I have an enormous hip to hip scar across my abdomen, almost inch wide in some areas.  Plus, they take away your navel and recreate a new one.  It takes a good week to be able to stand up straight.  The mess on my stomach is worse than the reconstructed breast, which by the way has a ton of hardened (necrosis) areas.  A TRAM really needs to be weighed long and hard.
Posts.Title: TRAM flap surgery vickie1 tam1953

I did all but my last 3 herceptins.  Developled cardiomyopathy... discovered during an elective surgery.  I, too, notice strange vision changes as of late but I chalk it up to being 42.  Lots of my friends told me I'd be holding the newspaper far away once I hit 40, like clockworks.  They were right.  I also can't seem to tolerate my contacts as well as I did pre-chemo.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2007 04:04AM TPPJ wrote: Hi Ladies,  I, too, am from the Jan. 2007 thread.  Last year at this time was a mind boggling fog.  But once you get started, you'll feel good that you are doing something about your situation and believe me, the time will fly.  A year later, my hair is back and I'm feeling completely normal.  And you really do get to a place where you can live a fairly normal life where you aren't thinking about it 24/7.  I never believed that day would come.  My best chemo tip:  Emend.  I did four A/C's and 12 taxols and never, ever had a day of nausea due to Emend.  Ask for it.  Best of luck all!
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63
